column1: Lansdale is a borough in Montgomery County
column2: Pennsylvania
column3: northwest of Philadelphia. It is a densely-populated commuter town
column4: with many residents traveling daily to Philadelphia using SEPTA Regional Rail's Lansdale/Doylestown Line. In 1900
column10: 316 people were inhabitants of Lansdale. The population was 16
column11: 269 at the time of the 2010 census.

column1: Lansdale is the center of the North Penn Valley
column2: a region which includes the surrounding townships and boroughs.

column1: The earliest known settlers in Lansdale were members of the Jenkins family. At the peak of its growth
column2: the Jenkins homestead occupied approximately 120 acres of land.  The construction of the North Pennsylvania Railroad (later absorbed into the Reading Railroad) during the 1850s contributed to rapid growth and expansion in Lansdale.  Employment opportunities generated by the railroad brought settlers
column3: housing
column4: and local businesses to the area.

column2: Lansdale Borough was officially incorporated and named after Phillip Lansdale Fox
column3: chief surveyor of the North Penn Railroad. By the naming conventions of the time
column4: it should have been called Jenkintown
column5: since the land immediately surrounding the train station was owned by the Jenkins family
column6: but there was already a town by that name along the rail line.The Jenkins Homestead and Lansdale Silk Hosiery Compy-Interstate Hosiery Mills
column7: Inc. are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

column1: Lansdale is home to a Kugel ball
column2: which is a dark grey granite sphere supported by a very thin film of water pumped from beneath its base. The Kugel Ball is located in Railroad Plaza
column3: adjacent to the SEPTA Lansdale/Doylestown Line train station in downtown Lansdale.  The plaza consists of a bricked patio with benches centered on the Kugel Ball and closes at 11:00 pm. An annual 5k race is held in June
column4: accordingly named the Kugel Ball race
column5: which starts and ends at the actual Kugel Ball in Railroad Plaza.

column1: The Lansdale Borough Hometown Heroes Banner Program is a living tribute created for the community to recognize and honor Lansdale Veterans who are serving or are veterans who have served in the United States Armed Forces.
According to the United States Census Bureau
column2: the borough has a total area of 3.1 square miles (8.0 km2)
column3: all land. It has a hot-summer humid continental climate (Dfa) and the hardiness zone is 6b. The average monthly temperature ranges from 30.2 °F in January to 74.7 °F in July. [1] The average annual absolute minimum temperature is -0.4 °F. [2]

column1: Lansdale has a city manager form of government with a mayor and a nine-member borough council.  On June 4
column3: local chiropractor G. Andrew Szekely was appointed by council resolution to serve the remaining 18 months of the term of Mayor Michael DiNunzio. Szekely won a full four-year term in November 2009. The current mayor of Lansdale is Garry Herbert
column4: who was voted into office in January

column1: The borough is part of the First Congressional District (represented by Rep. Brian Fitzpatrick)
column2: Pennsylvania's 53rd Representative District (represented by Rep. Steve Malagari) and the 24th State Senate District (represented by Sen. Bob Mensch).

column1: The community is a part of the North Penn School District. K-6 public elementary schools in Lansdale include Gwynedd Square Elementary
column2: Knapp Elementary
column3: Oak Park Elementary
column4: Inglewood Elementary
column6: and York Avenue Elementary. Penndale Middle School serves grades 7–9. The area public high school is North Penn High School in Towamencin Township.

column1: The borough is also home to Mater Dei Catholic School of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Philadelphia. It was formerly home to St. Stanislaus School. In January 2012
column2: the archdiocese announced that St. Rose of Lima School in North Wales would be merging with St. Stanislaus
column3: with students attending classes in Lansdale at St. Stanislaus. The newly combined school was renamed from St. Stanislaus to Mater Dei
column4: Latin for "Mother of God."

column1: Calvary Baptist School is a pre-K-12th grade Christian school. Lansdale area private high schools include Lansdale Catholic High School and Dock Mennonite Academy. Dock is in Towamencin Township.
The DeSales University Lansdale Area Campus is an institute of higher education
column2: with a campus specifically designed for adult students.

column1: Lansdale is served by the daily online newspaper The Alternative Press of North Penn
column2: owned and operated by Treacy Media Holdings
column3: LLC
column4: and edited by Towamencin Township native Tony Di Domizio
column5: and the daily print newspaper The Reporter
column6: owned by the Journal Register Company and having a circulation of 16
column10: WNPV (1440 AM) is a radio station broadcasting a news/talk/sports format that is licensed to Lansdale.

column1: North Penn Television is a television station owned by the North Penn School district that broadcasts the North Penn School District Board of School Directors meetings
column2: along with various events around the school district such as sports games and concerts.
Lansdale has been home to the popular music and entertainment venue
column3: The Underground
column4: which is owned and operated by Round Guys Brewing Company.

column1: The main east–west street in Lansdale is Main Street (Pennsylvania Route 63)
column2: which runs northwest–southeast. The main north–south street is Broad Street
column3: which runs southwest–northeast. Pennsylvania Route 363 begins at PA 63 on the western edge of Lansdale and heads southwest on Valley Forge Road. The Lansdale interchange of the Pennsylvania Turnpike Northeast Extension (Interstate 476) is located to the west of the borough in Towamencin Township and connects to PA 63.Lansdale is served by SEPTA Regional Rail's Lansdale/Doylestown Line via Lansdale station in downtown
column4: the Pennbrook station in the southern part of the borough
column5: and the 9th Street station in the northern part of the borough
column6: with service to Center City Philadelphia and Doylestown along with intermediate points. Three SEPTA Suburban Division bus routes serve Lansdale: the Route 94 connects the southern part of Lansdale with the Montgomery Mall and Chestnut Hill
column7: the Route 96 connects Lansdale with the Norristown Transportation Center in Norristown
column8: and the Route 132 connects the borough with the Montgomery Mall and Telford.Lansdale is the headquarters of the Pennsylvania Northeastern Railroad
column9: a short-line freight railroad. The Pennsylvania Northeastern Railroad operates the Lansdale Yard in the borough and provides freight rail service out of Lansdale to several points in the northern suburbs of Philadelphia on SEPTA-owned lines. The railroad interchanges with CSX Transportation in Lansdale.

column2: which is owned by the borough
column3: provides electricity to most of Lansdale
column4: with portions of the borough receiving electricity from PECO Energy Company

The North Penn Water Authority provides water to Lansdale and some surrounding areas. Sewer service in Lansdale is provided by the borough
column6: which operates a wastewater treatment facility. Trash and recycling collection in Lansdale is provided by contracts with private haulers
column7: although the borough has plans for a single hauler serving all residents.
